question: What nonrenewable natural resource is used to make electrical energy?

content.source_1: Coal is a natural resource and a fossil fuel formed from ancient plant matter.
content.source_2: Fossil fuels such as coal are considered nonrenewable because they take millions of years to form and are depleted when used.
content.source_3: In coal-fired power stations, coal is burned to produce steam that drives turbines to generate electricity.
content.source_4: Uranium ore is a mined natural resource and is nonrenewable because it is finite and not replenished on human time scales.
content.source_5: Nuclear power plants generate electricity using uranium fuel through nuclear fission (not by burning fossil fuels).
content.source_6: Power plants are engineered around a single primary fuel type (e.g., a coal plant uses coal; a nuclear plant uses uranium), with those fuels being mutually exclusive within a given plantâ€™s operations.
